Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi All, Has anyone experienced a herpes outbreak during chemo? I'd never had one before (not even a fever blister!), but since my port insertion, I've had a red and burning area at the edge of the cut. Every month it seems to flare up right after chemo and then get better towards the end of the three week hiatus. However, tonight it looks like it's got blisters on it. It itches and burns. I'm having my next round of chemo this Wednesday.Â Scary. But then, can anyone tell me what is not scary about this whole breast cancer process? Thanks, Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Herpes Simplex? HeatherBLocklear lilith

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I am offering a reward of a TWO LB box of Leonidas Belgian chocolates to whoever has the guts to come down to south Texas and yank my drain. I swear I won't cry, moan, flinch, or sock you in the eyeball. I just want the blasted thing OUT OF MY BODY. Unfortunately, I have been reduced to bribing my sisters on this forum. When the BS refused to pull the plug last week, I tried to bully his office staff into doing the deed. "Dr. So-and-So said you have the green light to unleash me," I told them, but alas they would not listen. In the meanwhile, I drag the blasted thing with me everywhere: to the supermarket, in the classroom, to gatherings and meetings. Also, I'm worried about infections, although I guess a lymphoma would be worse. Why won't it stop draining? Why, oh why??????? OK, those chocolates are waiting! Come one, come all. Love, Annie Camel Candy Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: REWARD! Box of CHOCOLATES! HeatherBLocklear AnneW

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Oops, I should have read the posts above before asking my question. Mea maxima culpa. Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Double mastectomy and recurrence? HeatherBLocklear TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I really need your input yet again. I'm wrapping up the boosts of my radiation (only two more to go). I started on October 27, so it's been eight weeks. At the same time, I'm taking 2,500 mgs of Xeloda, five days a week with two days (Saturday and Sunday) off. I am so exhausted I can hardly function. I feel totally drained, completely wrung out. Is this a sign that my cancer is progressing rapidly? I am so scared and so tired I don't know what to do. When I ask the oncologist if I should feel so drained, she simply says that "everyone gets fatigued on radiation." This, however, isn't simple fatigue; it's major exhaustion. Love to all, Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Please, please tell me if this is to be expected. HeatherBLocklear TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I had a vacuum biopsy (three punches) yesterday morning. Today my breast really aches (it seems even to hurt up the inside of my arm), and the veins are blue and quite apparent under the skin. Is this a normal reaction to the trauma of the biopsy? Thanks, Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Aching tender breast HeatherBLocklear HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I guess this is yet another idiotic question, but I'm still hoping for some helpful input. The shoulder where my PET/CT scan showed uptake has been hurting me a lot since yesterday. The pain is deep down inside the joint itself, occasionally radiating down my upper arm. The small "knot" of bone on top of the shoulder is very tender to the touch, too, although nothing seems hot/swollen/visibly inflamed this time. Is this typical of bone mets? If so, what am I supposed to do? I believe I cannot take aspirin because I'm on Xeloda. Can anyone tell me if that's true? Also, I hate pain killers and will not take them unless they're literally forced down my throat with an Alsatian goose funnel. I've not told "my" medical team about this new development because a.) I'm battling with finals and research papers this week, and b.) I'm sick and tired of their silly faces. Please give me some advice/guidance. Love, Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bone mets and pain HeatherBLocklear MariaC

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Dearest Elephant Sisters, First, a long-overdue wish for the most positive 2009 possible. May all of us get good news, experience remission, and get on with our lives without the constant pressure of the beast on our backs. I haven't posted in a while because my life has been in a bit of an uproar. DH and I went to France over the Christmas holidays, and spent three glorious weeks with my daughters and grandkids. I can't even begin to describe how wonderful it was to see them again, and especially to hold those little babies in my arms and sniff their mushroomy little heads. They're all so new and soft and clean and fresh -- it's a miracle. The biggest problem is that I was so exhausted the whole time I was there. I'd been diagnosed with bone mets shortly before we left, so my spirits were not the highest. Unfortunately, it was also very cold and damp in Europe, so every ache and pain I usually have was exacerbated. Then I caught the 'flu. My daughters were very unhappy about how immoble I was -- nearly unable to walk through town or go anywhere else with them, I was quite a drag. I am so sorry that part of my visit was a disappointment -- one always wants to make one's children as happy as one can. However, here is my present conundrum: my aches and pains were so bad while I was in France that I started taking Vicodin merely to be functional. I'm NOT a pill person -- I actually never had taken anything stronger than an aspirin before diagnosis. When I got back home, my oncologist ordered a bone scan as follow-up for the PET/CT scans that showed hotspots before I left. Here's the mystery -- there is no correlation between the two. Wherever things lit up on the PET/CT scan, there's absolutely nothing on the bone scan, nearly two months later. However, both my femurs show increased activity on the bone scan, whereas they did not light up the PET/CT scan. In the meanwhile, I continue to have intense, deep, aching pain in hips, shoulder, and legs that can only be relieved by Ibuprofen 600 every 4-6 hours. The pain wakes me up nearly every night, sometimes several times. What is going on? I don't understand anything anymore. The oncologist has now prescribed regular X-rays of the femurs, and is keeping me on Xeloda and Zometa. In the meanwhile, I've developed numb chin and lower lip syndrome, even though nothing lit up on the bone scan in the skull or other head areas. Thanks to anyone who cares to respond. Love to all, Annie Camel Spit Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Happy New Year + Update HeatherBLocklear AnnNYC

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: HI all, I'm now in France with my daughters, and they are taking me around to practitioners of alternate medicine, nutritionists, etc. Last night I had the first of a series of acupuncture sessions that are supposed to revigorate the system and help get rid of toxins left over from chemo and radiation. I was also given a long list of herbal supplements to oderÂ from the Continent. As soon as I receive them, I'll post them here together with the effects they're supposed to have. Was also told to eat raw oysters, Kiwi fruit, organic honey, and as raw and natural a diet as possible. This morning they took me to a spa for a full-body treatment and collagen facial. Hot stones were applied here and there, the musc was soft Japanese, the lights were dim pastel, and the air smelled like jasmine. It was simply heavenly! An update on this complementary treatment plan as it unfolds can be expected. Happy and blessed holidays to all -- may God keep us all safe for yet another year. Love, Annie Camel Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Alternate treatments in Europe HeatherBLocklear portiasproudmom

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I woke up this morning to a nosebleed and a hoarse voice. Those were both expected. However --------------- the hugely swollen axillary lymph node (2.5 cm) that finally made me come home is gone!!!! It has deflated. I have checked and checked again to make sure I'm not imagining things, but it really isn't palpable anymore. I'm almost scared to believe this ... Has anyone else experiencedÂ so rapid aÂ response to chemo? Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Avastin kicking in! HeatherBLocklear NancyD

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I had a consultationwith my breast surgeon yesterday to explore options I might have for surgery once chemotherapy is over. He told me that even with a bi-lateral mastectomy, there is still a chance of breast cancer recurrence. I was flabbergasted. How can cancer recur in tummy fat? I'm really interested in hearing from those of you who have done extensive research on issues connected to breast cancer. I'd also like to know what you think is a woman's best chance to get rid of this Damocles's sword once and for all -- lumpectomy, unilateral mastectomy, bilateral mastectomy? Radiation or no radiation? He also said that the need for radiation is now being called into question when a woman is NED after chemo and surgery. Thanks so much for any input from anyone who cares to weigh in. Love to all, Annie Double Hump (but not for long). Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Recurrence after mastectomy??? HeatherBLocklear dtad

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: This Post was deleted by HeatherBLocklear. Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: update on my biopsy HeatherBLocklear Jenn51

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I started thinking about all the disadvantages of being bald, and decided to make a list. If anyone has a "favorite" disadvantage, please chime in. Here are my own choice disadvantages: -- I can't open the door to the UPS man without scrambling for my do-rag (which I can never find anyway). -- My lawn boy flees in horror when he sees me through a window. -- My head is cold. -- My wig slips and slides all over the place -- no traction on a billiard ball. -- When I go to the convenience store, someone is sure to yell, "Oh I knew someone once who had cancer!" -- When the ceiling fan is on, the wisps that still remain on my skull get into my eyes and nose. -- If I can get the shower water at a temperature where it doesn't scald my head, it's too cool for the rest of me. -- I hate the look of the root "holes" in my scalp. They creep me out! -- Whenever I've been asleep on my side, MY EARS STICK TO MY HEAD. Anyone have anything to add? Hugs to all, Annie Bald Head Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

They creep me out! -- Whenever I've been asleep on my side, MY EARS STICK TO MY HEAD. Anyone have anything to add? Hugs to all, Annie Bald Head Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What I hate MOST about being bald! HeatherBLocklear dhettish

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, Even though moderation in all things is best, it's a fact that many of us enjoy our wine (and other indulgences) on appropriate occasions. We also know that there's a link between alcohol consumption and BC, especially hormone receptive positive tumors. Although the study below is not terribly recent, I still find it nice to know there's something one can do in order to continue to enjoy that Chateauneuf du Pape or St. Emilion, and still be pro-active against BC or its recurrence. Cheers to all! AnnieÂ  http://www.mayoclinic.org/news2001-rst/857.html Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: For all the wine lovers among us HeatherBLocklear NancyD

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I'm wondering about the frequency of metastases while a BC patient is undergoing chemotherapy. I'm especially concerned about mets to the lungs since I've developed a small but phlegmy cough over the past five days.Â Are mets during chemoÂ a common occurence? Thanks to all, Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Dear Fellow Elephant Cows, I want to recommend the following book to everyone at all stages of this journey: The Red Devil: To Hell with Cancer and Back by Katherine Russell Rich. It's dark, it's deep, it's totally hilarious!Â  Rich chronicles her voyage along the dark path that we all travel, detailing every agonizing step with uproarious dark humor. I guarantee you will love this book and be inspired by her brave battle which is still ongoing more than 20 years after she was first diagnosed with Stage IV breast cancer. Happy, hilarious reading! Annie Camelephant http://www.amazon.com/Red-Devil-Hell-Cancer-Back/dp/0609603213 Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: FANTASTIC book by Stage IV BC Sister! HeatherBLocklear HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, Here I am again, with new stupid questions. How often doesn one apply the cream? One person on my medical team told me three times a day, another said twice. Which one is it? Also, does one wash it off after each application, or merely wait for the next morning's shower? How soon does one start to see burnt skin? Can one prevent it with the cream? Is it normal to feel tired after radiation, or is it because I've been so anxiety-driven over the past few weeks that I'm drained this evening? (I did go straight from the hospital to campus and taught a full day.) Thanks to all, Annie, aka Devastatingly delicious camel droppings Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Does it depend solely on the skill of the reader? Are there any symptoms of bone mets? Where do bone mets typically go first? Scared to death again tonight. What a life. Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

When I got back home, my oncologist ordered a bone scan as follow-up for the PET/CT scans that showed hotspots before I left. Here's the mystery -- there is no correlation between the two. Wherever things lit up on the PET/CT scan, there's absolutely nothing on the bone scan, nearly two months later. However, both my femurs show increased activity on the bone scan, whereas they did not light up the PET/CT scan. In the meanwhile, I continue to have intense, deep, aching pain in hips, shoulder, and legs that can only be relieved by Ibuprofen 600 every 4-6 hours. The pain wakes me up nearly every night, sometimes several times. What is going on? I don't understand anything anymore. The oncologist has now prescribed regular X-rays of the femurs, and is keeping me on Xeloda and Zometa. In the meanwhile, I've developed numb chin and lower lip syndrome, even though nothing lit up on the bone scan in the skull or other head areas. Thanks to anyone who cares to respond. Love to all, Annie Camel Spit Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Happy New Year + Update HeatherBLocklear AnnNYC

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I'm starting this thread to find out if aÂ hunch of mine has any basis in reality (yes, yes, I know; we're always trying to find a reason!). Here goes: I was reading Katherine Russell Rich's book, The Red Devil: To Hell with Cancer and Back last night, and was startled to find sheÂ discovered her tumor when she was in the desperate last days of a failing marriage. "I remember thinking if I didn't get out of that marriage quickly, I was going to get cancer," she writes. When I was taking chemotherapy, two women at the clinic on the same schedule as me started discussing their lives one morning. One was convinced sheÂ developed cancerÂ because her husband was being released from the penitentiary (!), and wanted to come home. "It got me out of having Jorge back in the house," she wrily observed. Â "When he found out I had cancer, coming home wasn't nearly as attractive anymore." The other woman said she was so sick of her job that she was nearly happy to have BC because it gave her an excuse to quit and take care of herself for the first time in her life. When I discovered my lump, I was living in a place I hated (although I liked what I was doing there). I'd get up every morning, look out the window, and think, "dear Lord, please get me out of here." Well, He did, but not quite the way I'd planned ... Is there a connection between desperation and developing tumors? Maybe these cases are all coincidental and random. But I wonder. Love to all, Annie Camel Fart (hehe) Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Does desperation play a role in developing breast cancer? HeatherBLocklear dlb823

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I'm wondering about the topic in the subject sentence above, and also how much fluid is normal. My BS told me to call his office for drain removal already last Friday if there was less than 25 cc of fluid per day, and I'm still up around 75 or 80 cc five days post surgery. Isn't this an awful lot? Thanks for any info you care to give. Annie Camel Drain Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Existential breast cancer question du jour:Â  Why is it that when all the other hair on my person has falled out, I still have to shave under my arms? Someone, somewhere, is having a small joke at my expense. Annie Camel Fur Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Oh, the irony of it all! HeatherBLocklear otter

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Dear Everyone, I'llÂ answer all the wonderful PMsÂ little by little in between tests and appointments of one type and another. It really goes to show what this site and all you women have become to me that the first thing I did when I got home was to come to the forum to see what was cooking. I didn't cry when I got my diagnosis, but I cried when I read your messages.Â  I'm wondering how standard all the tests my doctor have prescribed are. I think he's figuring my cancer is pretty advanced (although it only appeared suddenly in late November or early December). He has prescribed a bone scan, pelvic and abdominal scan, lung X-ray, blood tests (tumor markers), urinalysis, a Muga scan, EKG, and I don't know what else.Â Is this common procedure? Otherwise of course I'm scared, especially of metastases, but I'll be damned if I'll let this bastard steal away the life I have worked so hard to build! I may go down, but I'll go down fighting. I just never want to go back to camel land again, except to pack up my belongings. I never want to see sheep tied up in front of a butcher shop for days without food and water, waiting forÂ their appointment in Samarra; I never again want to see animal body parts washing down the streets in the rain; people beating skinny horses straining to pull carts that are much too loaded for them; or be toldÂ over and overÂ that I need to convert to Islam. I want to be at home, with my own hard-working and brightÂ students, my dear colleagues, my good friends, and my beloved family. I always liked armadillos better than camels anyway. :-) Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Hi all HeatherBLocklear Sassa

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, Of course, being unable to sleep at night due partly to jet lag and time change and partly to bone-deep fear, I've been up all night fooling around on the Internet, looking for information. Here's my latest finding: chemotherapy not only makes the hair on your head fall out; it makes all your hair fall out. All of it. Here's the upside: IÂ canÂ become the first super-annuated porn star in movie history. Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Future Film Star HeatherBLocklear AnneW

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, Well, here we go again -- Annie of the embarrassing questions! I had my fourth chemo today, and since I didn't sleep one nanosecond of the first night following the other three, I'm fiddling with the idea of experimenting with an Ambien this evening. Here's my question: following the advice of the women on this board, I'm really tanking up on water. Could I possibly sleep through the night and not notice I need to use the restroom? Ahem. Sorry. Annie Full of H2O Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

May I suggest this film to everyone? You might already have seen it, in which case I apologize for being redundant. What I loved about the documentary is that it is both realistic and guardedlyÂ optimistic for all of us going through the hell of breast cancer. Most importantly, it doesn't purport to teach us any lessons except, perhaps, the importance of perseverance and just plain guts. Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I'm the person in North Africa going to France for evaluation of a large breast mass. I heard today I'm slated for an ultrasound on December 17. Am I the biggest coward history has ever known, or do other people get this terrified too? I keep bursting into tears at the strangest moments, and can't seem to get control of myself. Although I keep telling myself I'll deal with whatever comes my way, I'm falling apart at the seams. What on earth will happen if I get a diagnosis of cancer? Will I tear my hair out and my clothes off and run screaming down the street, LOL? I come from a family of very stoical women, so I'm feeling like a terrible wuss. Thanks for hearingÂ me out. AnnieÂ  Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, Now that my sore scalp, hoarse voice,Â and runny nose are finally easing up, I find I've got aÂ seriously sore mouth and throat. So far, no chancre sores (knocking on wood). I know I've seen a thread on this forum about mouth care during chemo, but now that I need it, IÂ naturally cannot track it down. Can anyone either show me where that thread is, or else give me the benefit of her personal experience? Thanks so much to anyone who helps. Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Advice for sore mouth and throat HeatherBLocklear HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Dear all, In response to the weekend's dismal news of three new diagnoses of brain mets plus the fact that I myself have recently been put on Xeloda (and, like everyone else,Â worry aboutÂ brain mets), I looked around a bit to see if there's any relation between the two. What I found is that Xeloda is considered promising for brain mets since it's one of the few chemotherapy agents that appears to cross the blood-brain barrier. This might be something everyone here knows already -- I tend, sometimes, to discover medical stuff long after it's old news to my sisters at BC.org. However, in case anyone else is as interested in this piece of news as I am myself, I thought I'd passÂ along the pertinentÂ snippet from the article together with a link to the BrainMets.org site where it's currently posted: One of the more recent agents that has been a focus of attention for its effectiveness against brain metastases is capecitabine (Xeloda), an oral fluoropyrimidine which is converted first by the liver, then intracellularly by the cancer cells into 5-FU, or fluorouricil.Â  It has been reported in Phase II trials to actually cause responses in 20 to 25 percent of patients who have measurable brain metastases.Â  The M.D. Anderson group did report on the combination of Xeloda and Temodar (temozolomide), although it's not clear how much Temodar contributes, since Xeloda alone has also been reported to cause regression in brain metastases.Â  Temodar as a single agent hasn't seemed to be particularly effective against breast cancer brain metastases.Â  The only way to know what the contribution of Temodar is would be to do a randomized trial of Xeloda, with or without Temodar.Â  http://www.brainmetsbc.org/index.php?q=node/42 Love to all, Annie Edited to add yet another link to a study showing complete brain mets response to Xeloda therapy. http://www.ima.org.il/imaj/ar03nov-21.pdf Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Xeloda for brain mets HeatherBLocklear VickiG

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Dear All, Following two axillary failures within a very short time, my medical team has now put me on Xeloda, 5 X 500 mg a day, in addition to radiation. Can anyone share with me what I can expect from this treatment? Will my hair fall out again? Will I be bothered with nausea (I have to work)? What about other SEs? Believe me, any help or information will be deeply appreciated. Love, Annie Camel Bunions (still young and gorgeous) Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Dearest all, How wonderful to turn on the computer in my own office in my own house and find all these messages from everyone! I think I've never felt as surrounded and supported in my life as I do now. Thank you for your enormous kindness and patience with me through these months. I know I've often been a pain in the butt, and that I was concentrating a lot on myself when other people were in equal or greater pain. I'm just home from the hospital where I spent the day with the wonderful t*t man and my sweet mother who came down to be with me too. The diagnosis is triple negative bc; unusual in someone my age. But there it is. I will have the results of the bone scan, tumor markers, pelvic scan, and lung x-ray on Monday when I meet with t*tMouse to discuss protocol in detail. So far, however, he has said he wants to try to shrink the mass through chemo, and will try to get me into some sort of study. This kind of BC is highly aggressive, but he assures me he's not yet lost a single of what he calls his "triples." I hope I won't be the first one. I am so happy to be home -- I guess I'll have to go back to North Africa to wrap things up with the landlord, try to sell some of my furniture etc., but otherwise I'm going to concentrate on getting as strong and well as I can before the fall semester starts in August. I guess I'm going over on the just diagnosed board now. Love to all of you. I don't think you will ever know how isolated I felt over there, and how much comfort I got from all of you and from this forum. You were truly my anchor. Annie Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Results HeatherBLocklear SoapMaker

Posts.Content: HeatherBLocklear wrote: Hi all, I know nobody can answer this question, and am also aware that this is a support forum, not a medical response site. But anxious as I am, I'm wondering about the following: I actually had a negative sonogram of the affected breast in July, 2006, in addition toÂ the clear mammogram this past mid-June, 2007. I find it so odd that I all of a sudden have a pingpongÂ  ball-sized mass in that breast. I thought breast cancer took years to grow??!! Are some lesions more fast-growing than others? Thanks, Annie PS: Yes, looking for reassurance. I can't help it, I guess. Annie Camel Tail Dx 2/23/2008, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
